content:
I am having trouble the very first exercise of the book Categorical Logic and Type Theory:

Prove: Cartesian liftings are unique up-to-isomorphism (in a slice): if fff and f′f'f′ with cod(f)=cod(f′)cod(f) = cod(f')cod(f)=cod(f′) are both Cartesian over the same map, then there is a unique vertical isomorphism ϕ:X≃X′\phi: X \simeq X' ϕ:X≃X′ with f′∘ϕ=ff' \circ \phi = ff′∘ϕ=f.

So let p:E→Bp : \mathbb{E} \to \mathbb{B}p:E→B be a functor. To say that f:X→Y,f′:X′→Yf : X \to Y, f' : X' \to Yf:X→Y,f′:X′→Y in E\mathbb{E}E are both Cartesian over u:B(I,J)u: \mathbb{B}(I,J)u:B(I,J) means that if:

pf=pf′=upf = pf' = upf=pf′=u and ∀g:E(Z,Y),∀w:B(pZ,I)\forall g : \mathbb{E}(Z,Y), \forall w : \mathbb{B}(pZ, I)∀g:E(Z,Y),∀w:B(pZ,I) such that pg=u∘wpg = u \circ wpg=u∘w

then there exist uniquely determined maps h:Z→X,h′:Z→X′h: Z \to X, h': Z \to X'h:Z→X,h′:Z→X′ in B\mathbb{B}B such that ph=ph′=wph = ph' = wph=ph′=w and f∘h=g,f′∘h′=gf \circ h = g, f' \circ h' = gf∘h=g,f′∘h′=g

image.png

I don't know where to begin, so I specialize to the case where ppp is the codomain fibration cod:Set→→Setcod : Set^{\to} \to Setcod:Set→→Set, and now I can think about how everything works inside SetSetSet:

image.png

The UP of Cartesian morphisms gives me two pullbacks over the same cospan I→J←YI \to J \leftarrow YI→J←Y and pullbacks are unique up to isomorphism so this works.

So then this should also work for cod:B→→Bcod : \mathbb{B}^{\to} \to \mathbb{B}cod:B→→B assuming B\mathbb{B}B has pullbacks, because I can again flatten things down to the base category and work there. Now the proposition mentions Cartesian liftings are unique up-to-isomorphism (in a slice).

Does this mean that just from knowing that a map is Cartesian means that the fibers of the functor are always in slice categories, in which case this same strategy should always work? I don't see how this follows just from the definition of a Cartesian map, although all the examples I have seen so far in the book do fit this pattern.

A cartesian lift is unique only once its codomain is fixed, and by unique we mean unique up to unique iso. But iso... in which category? In the slice of E\mathbb EE over the chosen codomain. I believe this is what Jacobs means here, not that every fibration has slices as fibers :)
This is a general pattern in UP: the objects are determined by unique isomorphism but that iso is in a specific category, e.g. co/limits are determined up to unique iso of co/cones. Which category one has to look at is usually something one can infer from the rest of the definition, so hardly explicitly mentioned as here.

Re the specific exercise: the general tactic to prove such things is to pit the two UP of fff and f′f'f′ against each other, leveraging uniqueness to show that the two universal arrows you get are necessarily inverse to each other.
I'll leave it to you from here. If you want more hints/a detailed solution just ask.
Thanks for the reply. Think I need to spend a bit more time thinking about this, but I won't ask for any more hints for now.

I have a question about the term "lift".

As I understand, a regular lift is connecting a cospan into a commuting triangle, so for example if the result is g=f∘hg = f \circ hg=f∘h then we say the lift is of ggg along hhh to fff.

Are cartesian lifts a version of a lift as described here? I am confused because going with the names in my diagram, the terminology in the book says that a cartesian morphism f:X→Yf : X \to Yf:X→Y is a cartesian lifting of uuu, but this doesn't look like the regular lift.

For consistency it seems it would be more appropriate to say that we are lifting ggg along www or I could even understand lifting www "up" to E\mathbb{E}E, but not "of uuu to fff" because uuu is just the image of fff under ppp. This is consistent with the book, but why are we calling lifting of uuu to YYY as fff (translating "fff to eee" from nLab to "uuu to YYY" with the names I used)?

Is the codomain of the lift the object YYY in my diagram? I think your hint is saying that the lift of uuu is unique as it exists as an object of E/Y\mathbb{E}/YE/Y? I still don't see how to get the proof from this right away, but it took me a while to clear my confusion about the lifting issue first, so it might be not that far from reach, assuming this is all correct now.
It is also a lift, but at a higher level: lifting a functor between categories, rather than a morphism within a category.

Putting aside the fibration condition, let's say p:C→Dp : C \to Dp:C→D is any functor. There's a category called [1][1][1] which consists of two objects 000 and 111 and a single nonidentity morphism 0→10 \to 10→1. Giving a functor from [1][1][1] to DDD is the same as giving a morphism of DDD, namely, the image of the nonidentity morphism of [1][1][1]. So, we can identify a morphism uuu of DDD with a functor u:[1]→Du : [1] \to Du:[1]→D. Then finding a morphism fff of CCC with p(f)=up(f) = up(f)=u is the same as lifting u:[1]→Du : [1] \to Du:[1]→D to a functor f:[1]→Cf : [1] \to Cf:[1]→C.

That looks good! Whenever you have two things with a universal property you play them off against each other in this general way and show they're isomorphic. I always tell the story of the two cowboys who both claim to be the fastest gun in the West. To settle who is best they fight a duel. And if they both win, they're isomorphic!
Yeah it should have been more obvious after @Matteo Capucci (he/him) 's hint but I had to first work out a simpler example of this with pullbacks before it properly clicked what I was supposed to do
